A class to handle sequence preprocessing, barcode extraction, and complexity analysis for sequencing datasets.

scripts.error_correct module¶

scripts.error_correct.concatenate_fastqs(input_fastq_list, output_dir)[source]¶

Concatenate multiple FASTQ files into a single temporary FASTQ in output_dir.

Returns the path to the concatenated file.

scripts.error_correct.convert_txt_to_whitelist_mapping_df_from_path(whitelist_path)[source]¶

Read a umi_tools whitelist text file (single concatenated FASTQ) and build a mapping DataFrame identical to the old per-barcode function.

Parameters:

  • whitelist_path (str or Path) – Path to the whitelist txt file.

  • reverse_complement (bool) – Whether to reverse complement sequences.

Returns:

Mapping DataFrame with columns ‘original’ and ‘canonical’.

Return type:

pd.DataFrame

scripts.error_correct.plot_all_whitelists(barcodes, output_dir, reverse_complement, n_cols=4, dpi=300)[source]¶

Plot summaries of multiple barcodes in a grid layout using summarize_whitelist.

Parameters:

  • barcodes (list[Barcode]) – List of Barcode objects.

  • output_dir (str) – Directory where whitelist outputs are saved.

  • n_cols (int, optional) – Number of panels per row. Default is 4.

  • dpi (int, optional) – Figure DPI. Default is 300.

Returns:

fig – The figure object containing all barcode summaries.

Return type:

matplotlib.figure.Figure

scripts.error_correct.rc_and_swap(preceder: str, post: str, length: int) -> (<class 'str'>, <class 'str'>)[source]¶

Given original preceder and post, return new preceder_rc and post_rc for reverse‑complement mode: preceder_rc = RC(post), post_rc = RC(preceder).

scripts.error_correct.run_whitelist_on_concat_domains(fastq_path, output_dir, set_cell_number=None, prefix=None)[source]¶

Run umi_tools whitelist on a simplified FASTQ (concatenated barcodes only).

Parameters:

  • fastq_path (str or Path) – Path to the FASTQ file containing extracted barcodes.

  • output_dir (str or Path) – Directory to save whitelist outputs.

  • prefix (str, optional) – Prefix for naming log and output files (default = FASTQ basename).

scripts.error_correct.summarize_whitelist(barcode, output_dir, reverse_complement, fig=None, axs=None, figsize=(16, 4), dpi=300)[source]¶
Summarize a umi_tools whitelist for a single Barcode and plot 4 summary plots side by side:

  1. Bar chart: original sequences vs canonical sequences

  2. Histogram of group sizes

  3. Scatter: largest member vs group size

  4. Scatter: largest member vs sum of smaller members

Parameters:

  • barcode (Barcode) – Barcode object whose whitelist to summarize.

  • output_dir (str or Path) – Directory containing the whitelist output.

  • fig (matplotlib.figure.Figure, optional) – Pre-created figure. If None, new figure is created.

  • axs (array-like, optional) – Pre-created matplotlib axes to plot on. If None, new axes are created.

  • figsize (tuple) – Figure size if creating a new figure.

  • dpi (int) – Figure DPI if creating a new figure.

Returns:

Figure object used for plotting array-like: Axes array used for plotting

Return type:

matplotlib.figure.Figure

scripts.finder module¶

class scripts.finder.Barcode(name, preceder, post, length)[source]¶

Bases: object

scripts.finder.add_barcode(seq_df, bc_object)[source]¶

Extracts a barcode from sequences between a preceding and following pattern.

Parameters:

  • seq_df (pd.DataFrame or dask.DataFrame) – DataFrame containing a ‘sequence’ column.

  • bc_name (str) – Name of the barcode to create.

  • preceder (str) – Sequence preceding the barcode.

  • post (str) – Sequence following the barcode.

  • bc_length (int, optional) – Maximum length of barcode to extract. Defaults to 120.

Returns:

Updated DataFrame with barcode and quality columns.

Return type:

pd.DataFrame or dask.DataFrame

Example

>>> df = pd.DataFrame({"sequence": ["AAAXXXCCC", "AAAYYYCCC"]})
>>> BarcodeMapper.add_barcode(df, "AD", "AAA", "CCC", 3)
   sequence   AD  AD_qual
0  AAAXXXCCC  XXX     True
1  AAAYYYCCC  YYY     True
scripts.finder.add_multiple_barcodes(bc_objects, seq_df)[source]¶

Extracts all defined barcodes from sequences in a DataFrame.

Parameters:

seq_df (pd.DataFrame or dask.DataFrame) – DataFrame containing sequences.

Returns:

Updated DataFrame with all barcodes added.

Return type:

pd.DataFrame or dask.DataFrame

Example

>>> df = pd.DataFrame({"sequence": ["AAAXXXCCC", "AAAYYYCCC"]})
>>> mapper = BarcodeMapper(...initialize...)
>>> mapper.add_multiple_barcodes(df)
scripts.finder.add_umi(seq_df, umi_length=12)[source]¶

Extracts the first umi_length bases from the ‘sequence’ column as the UMI.

Parameters:

  • seq_df (pd.DataFrame or dask.DataFrame) – DataFrame containing a ‘sequence’ column.

  • umi_length (int) – Length of the UMI to extract. Default is 12.

Returns:

Updated DataFrame with ‘UMI’ and ‘UMI_qual’ columns.

Return type:

pd.DataFrame or dask.DataFrame

scripts.initial_map module¶

class scripts.initial_map.InitialMapper(db_path, seq_file, bc_objects, step_name, reverse_complement, design_file_path, umi_object=None)[source]¶

Bases: object

Extract and map barcodes from DNA sequences in FASTQ or TXT files.

This class reads sequence files, optionally reverse-complements them, extracts barcodes and UMIs, and merges with a design file to produce an initial mapping table in DuckDB.

Parameters:

  • db_path (str) – Path to DuckDB database file.

  • seq_file (str or list[str]) – Path(s) to input FASTQ or sequence files.

  • bc_objects (list) – List of barcode objects defining name, preceder, post, and length.

  • step_name (str) – Prefix for tables in DuckDB.

  • reverse_complement (bool) – Whether to reverse complement sequences before mapping.

  • design_file_path (str, optional) – Path to CSV file containing designed sequences.

  • umi_object (object, optional) – UMI object defining extraction parameters. Defaults to None.

Example

>>> mapper = InitialMapper(
...     db_path="db.duckdb",
...     seq_file="reads.fastq",
...     bc_objects=[...],
...     step_name="step1",
...     reverse_complement=True,
...     design_file_path="design.csv"
... )
>>> mapper.create_map()
create_map()[source]¶

Run the full mapping pipeline on all reads.

create_test_map(test_n_reads: int = 100)[source]¶

Run the mapping pipeline on a limited number of reads for testing.

Parameters:

test_n_reads (int) – Number of reads to process for testing. Defaults to 100.

Extract all barcode columns and compute their quality flags

extract_umi()[source]¶

Extract the UMI sequence and compute its quality flag

merge_design()[source]¶

Merge with design file if provided, or create default Designed column

preview_map()[source]¶

Preview the first 5 rows of the mapped table.

Returns:

A DataFrame of the first 5 rows in the initial mapping table.

Return type:

pandas.DataFrame

read_fastq()[source]¶

Read sequences from FASTQ/TXT files and create an initial sequence table.

If self.test_n_reads is set, only a limited number of reads will be read.

reverse_complement_fastq()[source]¶

Replace sequence column with its reverse complement

scripts.map_refiner module¶

class scripts.map_refiner.MapRefiner(db_path, bc_objects, column_pairs, reads_threshold, map_order=None, step_name='', descriptor='', design_file=None, output_figures_path=None, min_fraction_major_target=0.9, manual_ec_threshold=True, umi_object=None)[source]¶

Bases: object

A class to refine sequencing maps made through InitialMapper.

DEFAULT_MAP_ORDER = ['initial', 'quality', 'error_corrected', 'grouped', 'thresholded', 'barcode_exists', 'unique_target', 'designed']¶
apply_whitelist(output_dir, prev_table=None)[source]¶

Apply umi_tools whitelist to previous table: replace barcodes and AD sequences with canonical ones, then recalculate quality flags and ‘Designed’ based on canonical barcode. Saves results to a new table prefixed with error_corrected.

barcode_exists(previous_table='initial')[source]¶

Remove rows where any barcode column (except AD) is NULL or an empty string.

check_exists(check_table_name)[source]¶
close_connection()[source]¶
create_designed(previous_table='quality')[source]¶

Keep only rows where Designed == 1.

create_error_corrected(previous_table='quality')[source]¶

Perform error correction by generating a FASTQ from grouped barcodes, applying umi_tools whitelist, and updating the database with corrected barcodes.

create_grouped(previous_table='quality_designed')[source]¶
create_initial(parquet_path)[source]¶
create_quality(previous_table='initial')[source]¶

Keep only rows where all _qual columns are TRUE.

create_thresholded(previous_table)[source]¶
create_unique_target(previous_table)[source]¶

For each (key_cols, target_cols) pair, independently keep keys where the most abundant target accounts for ≥ self.min_fraction_major_target of reads. Then, keep rows that pass all filters.

generate_fastq_for_whitelist(output_dir=None, suffix='_barcodes_extracted.fastq', prev_table='quality')[source]¶

Generate a synthetic FASTQ file from the filtered previous table, using concatenated barcode for reads that pass quality checks.

Parameters:

  • output_dir (str or Path, optional) – Directory to save the FASTQ. Defaults to current working directory.

  • suffix (str) – Suffix for FASTQ filename.

  • prev_table (str, optional) – Name of the previous DuckDB table to use instead of initial table.

Returns:

Path to the generated FASTQ file.

Return type:

str

Parameters:

prev_table (str, optional) – Name of the DuckDB table to merge design info into. Defaults to seq if not provided.

plot_all_whitelists_from_summary(summary_df, n_cols=4, dpi=300)[source]¶

Plot summaries of multiple barcodes using precomputed summary_df instead of reading whitelist files again.

Parameters:

  • summary_df (pd.DataFrame) – DataFrame returned from summarize_canonical_subsequences, must contain columns [‘barcode’, ‘canonical’, ‘num_merged’, ‘largest_count’, ‘rest_count’].

  • n_cols (int, optional) – Number of panels per row. Default is 4.

  • dpi (int, optional) – Figure DPI. Default is 300.

Returns:

fig – Figure containing all barcode summaries.

Return type:

matplotlib.figure.Figure

Summarize counts of canonical subsequences (barcodes) per AD sequence from whitelist files, produce a summary table and optional plots.

Parameters:

  • save_dir (str or Path, optional) – Directory to save outputs.

  • plot (bool) – Whether to produce plots.

Returns:

summary table of barcodes with counts and group sizes.

Return type:

pd.DataFrame

plot_loss(ax=None, palette='rocket_r', text_offset=0, show_background=True)[source]¶

Plot loss across mapping steps showing total reads vs unique counts. Adds numeric count labels at the end of each bar.

Parameters:

  • save_path (str or None) – Optional path to save the plot.

  • ax (matplotlib.axes.Axes or None) – Optional existing axis to draw on.

  • palette (str) – Seaborn color palette name.

Returns:

The plotted axis.

Return type:

matplotlib.axes.Axes

plot_reads_histogram(previous_table, save_path=None, ax=None, **kwargs)[source]¶
refine_map_from_db(save_name=None, should_check_exists=False)[source]¶
save_loss_table(output_csv_path=None)[source]¶

Generates a table summarizing the counts and losses at each step of the mapping process.

Parameters:

output_csv_path (str or None) – If provided, saves the resulting DataFrame as a CSV file at this path.

Returns:

DataFrame summarizing unique counts, unique AD counts, total reads, and percentage losses at each mapping step.

Return type:

pd.DataFrame

scripts.plotting.plot_reads_histogram(map_df, save_path=None, ax=None, **kwargs)[source]¶

Plots a histogram of read counts on a log-log scale.

Parameters:

  • map_df (pd.DataFrame) – DataFrame containing at least a “count” column.

  • save_path (str, optional) – Path to save the figure.

  • ax (matplotlib.axes.Axes, optional) – Axis to plot on. If None, a new figure is created.

  • **kwargs (dict) – Additional keyword arguments passed to sns.histplot.

Returns:

Axis with the histogram plotted.

Return type:

matplotlib.axes.Axes

scripts.preprocess module¶

scripts.preprocess.load_and_shorten_files(seq_files, reverse_complement)[source]¶

Load sequence files (FASTQ, gzipped FASTQ, or TXT) as Dask DataFrame. For FASTQ files, keeps only every 4th line starting from line 1 (the sequence line).

Parameters:

  • seq_files (list of str or str) – List of file paths.

  • reverse_complement (bool) – Whether to apply reverse complement.

Returns:

Loaded sequences as a Dask DataFrame with column ‘sequence’.

Return type:

dask.DataFrame

scripts.preprocess.reverse_complement(seq)[source]¶
scripts.preprocess.reverse_complement_series(s: Series) → Series[source]¶

Returns the reverse complement of a pandas Series of DNA sequences.

Parameters:

s (pd.Series) – Series of DNA sequences.

Returns:

Series of reverse complemented sequences.

Return type:

pd.Series

Example

>>> s = pd.Series(["ATGC", "GATTACA"])
>>> BarcodeMapper.reverse_complement_series(s)
0       GCAT
1    TGTAATC
dtype: object
scripts.preprocess.save_parquet(df, path)[source]¶

Saves the mapped barcode DataFrame to a Parquet file with a progress bar.

Parameters:

path (str) – Path to save the Parquet file.

Returns:

None

Example

>>> mapper = BarcodeMapper(...initialize...)
>>> mapper.create_map()
>>> mapper.save_parquet("mapped_barcodes.parquet")
scripts.preprocess.shorten_seq_file(infile, outfile, chunk_size=400000)[source]¶

Fastest extraction of sequences (2nd line of each FASTQ record) to a text file. Works with plain FASTQ or gzipped FASTQ.

Parameters:

  • infile (str) – Input FASTQ or FASTQ.GZ file.

  • outfile (str) – Output text file (1 sequence per line).

  • chunk_size (int) – Number of lines to read at once (multiple of 4).

scripts.preprocess.time_it(func)[source]¶

Decorator to print how long a method takes to run.

scripts.umi_deduplicate module¶

Bases: object

Unified UMI Deduplication class combining simple counts and full UMI-tools pipeline.

align_sort_and_deduplicate_umis()[source]¶
counts_per_umi()[source]¶

Returns a DataFrame with counts of each UMI per barcode combination. Uses the quality_designed table in DuckDB.

generate_barcode_fasta_and_index(suffix='_barcodes')[source]¶

Save all unique concatenated barcodes as a new table, concatenating multiple columns with no separator.

generate_fastq(suffix='_umi_extracted.fastq')[source]¶

Generate a FASTQ from self.table_prefix.initial: - Read sequence = concatenated barcode columns - Read ID = UMI - Keep all rows (no deduplication) - Tracks progress using tqdm

merge_complex_with_step1_map(save=True)[source]¶

Merge the UMI-tools deduplicated counts CSV with the step1 map on barcode columns.

merge_simple_with_step1_map(save=True)[source]¶

Performs an inner merge of the current table with step1_map_name on the barcode columns (self.cols) and returns the result as a DataFrame.

scripts.umi_deduplicate.fastp_summary_df(output_dir)[source]¶
scripts.umi_deduplicate.run_fastp(input_dir, output_dir, script_path='../savio_jobs/fastp.sh')[source]¶

Run fastp on all .fastq.gz files in input_dir. Outputs as .fastq files. Submit the existing fastp.sh script as a SLURM array job.

Parameters:

  • input_dir (str) – Path to folder containing .fastq.gz files

  • output_dir (str) – Path to folder where output should be written

  • script_path (str) – Path to the existing fastp.sh script
